text:
Fort Tryon Park: A set of 3 views, photographed in the Park, of various features. No. 1 is northwards across the North (Hudson) River; No. 2 in the Park, while No. 3 is from Riverside Drive.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Fort Tryon Park.

text:
Fort Tryon Park: A southward view from a point in same on a line with West 196th Street and showing the southern half of this Park. The roadway on the left is Park Drive, a continuation of Fort Washington Ave., towards which the photographer is viewing and upon both sides of which appear buildings. The George Washington Bridge appears partially on the extreme right.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Fort Tryon Park - [196th Street (West).]

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A set of 3 views of the entrance to same from Riverside Drive (foreground). Note the bastion like fortifications atop both sides of same. This would be more or less on a line with West 195th Street.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A set of 2 views of the south side of the entrance from Riverside Drive (foreground, photographer thereon). Atop of same is a rock, fortress like structure. This entrance would be on a line with West 195th Street.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
(1) and (2)
Fort Tryon Park: A set of 2 view showing the north side of the Riverside Drive (foreground) entrance to same, and showing atop thereof, a fortress like embankment. This would be on a line with West 195th Street.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The automotive entrance viewed from the Drive (foreground) and which turns northward to the "Cloisters", the newly constructed medieval unit of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A vehicular entrance to this historic area, from Riverside Drive near West 195th Street. The bridge like structure appearing is a pedestrian walk, on sides of which appear fortress like embankments.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A set of 3 views of the colonnaded entrance to the Park from Riverside Drive (shown on the left). These grounds were known until recently as the C. K. G. Billings Estate.

July 30, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A northward view on Riverside Drive showing the grounds on the right with their colonnaded entrance. This area was formerly known as the C. K. G. Billings Estate; for earlier views and an account of same, see the Riverside files. This set consists of three views, No. 3 of which is in a southward direction.

July 30, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A northward view of same, showing a new Museum rising on this historic ground. Note Riverside Drive paralleling the North (Hudson) River and the Fort Lee Ferry dock at Dyckman Street. On the opposite side of the water are the Palisades of New Jersey. This set consisting of 3 views shows details of the inclusive view seen in No. 1.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A northward view of same, showing a new Museum rising on this historic ground. Note Riverside Drive paralleling the North (Hudson) River and the Fort Lee Ferry dock at Dyckman Street. On the opposite side of the water are the Palisades of New Jersey. original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
Fort Tryon Park: A northward view of same, showing a new Museum rising on this historic ground. Note Riverside Drive paralleling the North (Hudson) River and the Fort Lee Ferry dock at Dyckman Street. On the opposite side of the water are the Palisades of New Jersey. This set consisting of 3 views shows details of the inclusive view seen in No. 1.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

Fort Tryon Park: Three similar views photographed near the new Museum Building. Across the Hudson River appears Fort Lee, nestling at the foot of the Palisades. The Ferry boat shown in one of these views is progressing toward that point after leaving Dyckman Street.

June 22, 1936.
Views 2 & 3:--July 30, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: Fort Tryon Park - Small bridge.

text:
Fort Tryon Park: A small cottage in the Park on Fort Washington Ave. slightly north of the convergence of Northern and Fort Washington Aves. This is upon the former grounds of C. K. G. Billings. This structure bears No. 741 Fort Washington Ave; Northern Ave., appearing on the right where fencing is seen. June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Fort Washington Aven - St. Marks Place
North (Hudson) River - Shore and skyline - Manhattan - George Washington Bridge.
North (Hudson) River - Shore and skyline - Manhattan - George Washington Bridge.

text:
Fort Tryon Park: A set of 2 views showing the recently completed Cloisters; a medieval art treasure house of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The photographer is viewing northward and shows the southern side of same.

September 11, 1938.
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
